thread.title: Local athletes in college: Oct. 13, 2015 - Local Athletes in College
thread.title_full: Local athletes in college: Oct. 13, 2015 - Local Athletes in College - NorthJersey.com

author: JOHN ROWE
title: Local athletes in college: Oct. 13, 2015 - Local Athletes in College
text:
Lou Cirangle, Wayne; Jeff Albies, Hillsdale; Tommie Patterson, Paterson
Lou Cirangle has waited a long time to be recognized.
Now that he is, he’s enjoying every moment.
The longtime Wayne resident was inducted into the William Paterson University Hall of Fame on Sunday and will join the Old Timers Athletics Association of Greater Paterson’s hall Nov. 5.
Not bad for an 84-year-old who played basketball for a school that then was known as Paterson State Teachers College.
During an era that predated the shot clock and three-point field goals, Cirangle (1954-58) became the fourth player in Paterson State history to score 1,000 career points, and the first to do so during his junior year. His 1,528 points were good enough for second place on the school’s list at the time, and he still ranks seventh in Pioneer history.
Growing up in Paterson as the youngest of 12 born to Italian immigrants, Cirangle attended college on the GI bill after serving in the Korean War. He’s lived in Wayne since 1967.
Cirangle’s fellow inductees into the Old Timers Hall of Fame are longtime William Paterson baseball coach Jeff Albies and Kennedy basketball coach Tommie Patterson.
Albies, a Hillsdale resident, coached two William Paterson NCAA Division III championship teams (1992, 1996), and finished his career ranked eighth all time in Division III victories with a record of 862-401-15 in his 33 seasons. Thirty-one of his players went on to play professionally, including former Yankee Dan Pasqua and former Oriole Bruce Dostal.
Patterson, class of 1994, finished fourth in Pioneer scoring history, with 1,627 points. He holds the school single-game scoring record, with 47 points against Medgar Evers in 1991. He twice earned spots on the All-NJAC, All-ECAC and All-Metropolitan Basketball Writers Association first teams.
* William Paterson’s current men’s basketball team is ranked 16th nationally in the 2015-16 DIII News Preseason Top 25 poll. The Pioneers, led by 20th-year coach Jose Rebimbas, were 21-8 last season, reaching the NJAC tournament championship game and the second round of the NCAA tournament. They open their season Nov. 14 against Mount Union in the first round of Drew University’s Rose City Classic.
J.P. Garcia, Bergen Catholic
* Defensive back J.P. Garcia, a sophomore from Cedar Grove who played at Bergen Catholic, is a leader on Tufts’ defense. Tufts is off to its first 3-0 start since 2007 after beating Bowdoin, 43-24. Garcia has 15 tackles, fourth best on the team, including five for losses. He also has a 30-yard interception return.
Tamila Kadyer-Akhunova, Fair Lawn
* Tamila Kadyer-Akhunova of Ramapo College, a freshman from Fair Lawn, is the NJAC women’s tennis rookie of the week. She won singles and doubles matches in non-conference victories over Staten Island College and Mount St. Mary. Kadyer-Akhunova is 5-3 as the Roadrunners’ No. 2 singles player.
Email: rowe@northjersey.com
